title: Monday, 18th January, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

Morning

PM

Thought we might start with a pic of this chap

PM

11:01 am
PM

Boss of Deloitte

PM

Punit Renjen

PM

Withering piece from Lucy this morning

11:02 am
PM

http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz3xamHMqrO

PM

Taking his New Year msg apart

PM

Anyone in possession of even a normal IQ would wonder why they were working there

11:02 am
PM

It's very funny

PM

Couple of things to note

PM

Punit actually came from very humble beginnings

11:03 am
PM

Quartz has his history here: http://qz.com/3461...oitte-globals-ceo/

PM

But also worth noting that Deloitte are an important adviser to our new owners, Nikkei

PM

Does Lucy care? No

11:04 am
PM

Deloitte are doing all the integration stuff -- the FT takeover

PM

But the journalism here is independent, clearly

PM

Any enough of him

11:05 am
PM

I've known Deloitte were rubbish ever since the I first tried to do a US tax return

PM

Deloitte cost me $$$ -- and hundreds of wasted hours

undefined
11:05 am
PM

So Bryce

BE

Yes?

PM

Oil tanked again

11:05 am
BE

Iran, I guess.

PM

But this no longer affects us

PM

Kinda weird

11:06 am
PM

BP rises on fresh oil glut

PM

Footsie creeps ahead

PM

Markets all over the place

11:06 am
BE

Well, BP also rises on a SocGen upgrade, which we can get to later.

PM

hmm

BE

But it will be a slow session today, because of Martin Luther King Jr. Day

11:07 am
PM

Of course

PM

US has so many public holidays

BE

It's one of the nation's better aspects.

11:08 am
PM

I lose track

PM

Sure

undefined
11:08 am
PM

So, AMEC

Amec Foster Wheeler PLC (AMFW:LSE): Last: 406.20, up 17.9 (+4.61%), High: 414.70, Low: 381.80, Volume: 966.57k
BE

Samir Brikho exits.

11:09 am
PM

Stock gaps higher

PM

Love it when that happens

BE

We can say it's on the "2015 trading results are in line with expectations" guidance ......

11:10 am
BE

But really, it's because the number of reasons for Mr Brikho to exit were multiplying.

PM

John Connolly, Chairman, said: "Samir has been the Chief Executive for over nine years and has made a significant contribution to our development over this period, including the re-shaping and re-focusing of the business at the start of his tenure to build up the global company Amec Foster Wheeler is today. On behalf of the Board and everyone at Amec Foster Wheeler I thank Samir for his commitment and contribution. We wish him the best for the future."

PM

"Now bugger off"

11:10 am
BE

Indeed. The recent profit warning was unhelpful for shareholder relations.

PM

I added that last bit

BE

Though he has to wear at least part of the blame for buying Foster Wheeler at entirely the wrong price.

11:11 am
BE

Creating a combined entity whose market cap went on to erase the entire value of Foster Wheeler.

PM

oops

BE

And which required a quite painful refinancing. Though luckily, because it now owned Foster Wheeler, it had the scale to refinance the debt it only took on to buy Foster Wheeler.

11:12 am
BE

So it all worked out in the end. Except for Mr Brikho, for whom it didn't.

PM

And the dividend went of course

BE

And actually, the refinancing isn't confirmed yet. Tricky to change CEOs in the middle of that process.

11:14 am
BE

Due before the end of February. One assumes the CFO, who's now acting CEO, is in charge of that.

BE

Barclays says ...........

BE

[W]e see the move as the company embarking on the next phase of its development, aiming to fully capitalise on the Foster Wheeler integration of 2015. While a change in CEO always comes as a shock, and the transformation that the company has undergone since 2006 is significant, we feel that the shock warning and dividend cut of late 2015 left investors looking for someone to blame. Perhaps, the change in CEO can help satisfy those needs and enable investors to focus on the diversified nature of the business, insulated from oil pressures, the benefits of the synergies from the merger and the dividend yield which has again reached attractive levels, in our opinion.

11:15 am
BE

Note, interestingly, the CFO Iain McHoul doesn't want the top job.

BE

Doing it on a temporary basis only.

PM

Yeah, saw that

11:15 am
PM

Self preservation

BE

Merrill says ................

BE

This move comes after the weak earnings and cashflow update AMFW provided in
November which saw the dividend cut by 50%. AMFW today gave a further update
stating that there is no change to the expected trading for 2015 and 2016 has started
as expected. AMFW also continues to work through refinancing the balance sheet.
While there may be some concern that any management change precedes bad news, we
think that the market will view a management change in a positive light, in the hope
that the company can be reinvigorated in terms of its strategy and leadership.
There is no timeline on when further management announcements will be made.

11:16 am
BE

So, yeah, it's likely that he's taken the fall for bad decisions already done rather than bad decisions to come.

BE

We believe Amec Foster Wheeler should trade close to the multiples we assign to the
quality companies in Europe, due to the progression of profitability and cashflow
generation. We value Amec FW on 12x 16E PE, 10x EV/EBITDA and DCF using a WACC
of 9.0%. Assigning equal weightings to each measure, our price objective is GBP
7.50/US$11.50.
Risks: Industry activity levels: Our forecasts are based around an expectation that
commodity prices will continue to support an improving level of activity for oilfield
services from the oil companies. A material fall in oil and/or gas prices, in our view, will
see industry spending patterns change significantly. Project execution risk: A small
portion of Amec FW's contract awards are secured on an EPC basis in which the
contractor takes on full project execution on a turnkey basis. As a result, significant cost
overruns and/or project delays could have a negative impact on earnings. Currency risk:
Some of Amec FW's revenues are in USD (or USD-linked) while a part of its costs are
GBP-denominated. A significant depreciation in the USD could dampen Amec FW's
margins.

BE

That's the boilerplate on the Merrill note, which I include for completeness.

11:17 am
PM

So everyone really is happy to see the back of Brikho

BE

As I say, Foster Wheeler was a stinker. The profit warning and divi cut hasn't really helped either.

PM

Marrill's generalised base case is that things will get better

11:18 am
PM

Good to have such a positive attitude -- especially as a stockbroker

undefined
BE

While on the sector, Wood Group doing okay today.

11:18 am
John Wood Group PLC (WG.:LSE): Last: 586.50, up 13 (+2.27%), High: 588.00, Low: 570.00, Volume: 576.03k
BE

I've nothing to add to last week's (extremely cautiously written) story about Wood being tentatively shopped SNC ......

BE

...... I did forget to note last week, though, that Macquarie doesn't believe it'll happen.

11:20 am
PM

ah, ok

BE

CEO says not in the market for a major acquisition: SNC Lavalin has long
put the Oil & Gas sector at the heart of its expansion plans. We estimate that
the acquisition of Wood Group would result in Oil & Gas accounting for ~65%
of revenue. However, we reject the likelihood of a deal. SNC Lavalin’s new
CEO said on his first earnings call in November that there would be no major
acquisition until they demonstrate “quarter-after-quarter stability [with] no
surprises and continuing performance improvement”. To us, this precludes
any near-term deal on the size of Wood Group.

BE

But humour me if you will: An all-cash offer for Wood Group would result in
pro forma Net Debt EBITDA rising to in excess of 4.0x under most
reasonable acquisition premium assumptions. Given that direct peer AMFW
has said that 2.0x is a comfortable Net Debt EBITDA level, we estimate that
SNC Lavalin would want to offer ~50% of any deal consideration in paper.

11:20 am
BE

 In a sector where there have been some real humdingers over the past 12
months, our Underperform recommendation on Wood Group has not been our
best call. December’s trading update, did not as we had expected, trigger
further earnings downgrades. Indeed, together with recent acquisitions,
earnings have shown modest growth recently and we find our own forecasts
now marginally ahead of consensus.
 Although conscious that we also upgraded our Underperform on AMFW too
quickly in October, we believe the time is right to call the Underperform
recommendation on Wood Group quits. The market appears willing to support
a premium valuation on the name given its asset-light business model and
decent balance sheet. With no evidence that either of those will change in the
near term the catalysts for underperformance, certainly relative to the rest of
the sector, appear thin on the ground. Upgrade to Neutral.

BE

As I say, that's from Friday. But I forgot to share it then, so share it now.

undefined
11:21 am
PM

I have no fresh intel on Allied Minds, btw

PM

Very weak tho

Allied Minds PLC (ALM:LSE): Last: 315.00, down 14.8 (-4.49%), High: 331.60, Low: 311.00, Volume: 46.32k
11:22 am
PM

Suspect a few founder shareholders are following the example set by the former chairman

PM

And knocking a few out.

PM

It's still very liquid

11:23 am
PM

Might just note another IP company busy investing...

PM

http://www.investe...1601180700081105M/

PM

Imperial Innovations Group plc (AIM: IVO, 'the Group', 'Innovations') has committed £24.75 million to the new UCL Technology Fund ('the Fund') launched today. This is the first investment fund that UCL (University College London) has established to commercialise its multidisciplinary research.

Over the next five years the Fund is expected to invest up to £50 million to support ideas from academics in life sciences and physical sciences, and will be used for early-stage proof of concept funding, licensing opportunities and the formation of new spin-out companies.

11:24 am
PM

Some people have speculated in the past that Allied Minds and Imperial might merge their university businesses -- leaving the military stuff as a separate biz.

PM

But it's just speculation

BE

Oh, I'd also note there's a growing short in Allied Minds, at least against its rather small market cap.

11:24 am
PM

Is there now?

BE

Up to 14.7% of free float now. Which puts it top ten in terms of most shorted.

PM

hmm

11:25 am
BE

But as I say, very small free float magnifies that.

BE

The other interesting one on that list is Ocado, which is now up to 19.3% of its free float on loan.

Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 243.00, down 11.6 (-4.56%), High: 256.60, Low: 239.40, Volume: 1.69m
11:26 am
BE

Fourth most-shorted large cap, behind Sainsbury, Morrison and Carillion. I have a chart somewhere.

BE

BE

As in, back to 2012 levels.

11:28 am
BE

Which I think might be why we're getting rather a lot of noise about Ocado at the moment.

BE

One group of people are saying, "the international deal's not arrived so it's just a grocer with 1% UK market share, no pricing power and over-expensive infrastructure."

BE

And another group of people are saying, "hold on, the international deal might not have arrived because it's going to be bigger and more exciting and unicorn-y and transformational and stuff."

11:30 am
PM

And which group are you in Bryce?

PM

Welcome to ML

PM

You just report, eh?

11:30 am
BE

I'm with @cheeckychappy, who sums things up more succinctly than I ever could.

undefined
PM

Oh, look -- who'd have thought...

11:31 am
PM

Phorm (AIM: PHRM), a leading advertising-technology company and first party data platform provider, is pleased to announce that it has raised approximately US$1 million before expenses via a subscription for 44,821,076 new ordinary shares of nil par value each in the capital of the Company (the "Subscription Shares") at a price of 1.55 pence per Subscription Share (the "Subscription").

BE

(@ROTR: Sainsbury short is partly due to the Qatar stake, which reduces its free float so makes it look worse than it is.)

PM

How does this company continue to find mugs to buy into it's placings?

11:32 am
BE

That's a mystery.

PM

http://www.investe...1601180700081110M/

BE

I see it's now a "first party data platform provider".

11:32 am
BE

I wonder what that means? I assume nothing.

PM

The Board is currently forecasting a further decrease in the Company's average cash burn rate to between US$0.63 million and US$0.71 million per month during 2016, with the forecast total cash requirement for 2016 being between US$7.5 million and US$8.5 million.

PM

Shouldn't ot have "creepy" somewhere in the description?

11:33 am
Phorm Corporation Ltd (PHRM:LSE): Last: 1.50, down 0.125 (-7.69%), Volume: 353.46k
BE

I do enjoy Phorm. It always leads down the most fascinating rabbit holes.

BE

For example, I just randomly chanced upon this: https://www.whatdo..._of_rns_from_phorm

11:34 am
BE

Someone getting seriously irritated with the FSA about Phorm's disclosure.

BE

La La La La La. Three ply toilet paper for your bottoms.. Everyone
else gets pink ones or ends up using fingers.

PM

What??

11:35 am
BE

I'm not sure. This isn't the tone of normal FSA correspondences.

PM

I think we should move on

undefined
11:36 am
BE

So, Home Retail then.

Home Retail Group PLC (HOME:LSE): Last: 153.15, down 0.45 (-0.29%), High: 159.70, Low: 152.10, Volume: 1.11m
BE

Aussies buying Homebase.

11:37 am
BE

Hey, ROTR: successful Aussie acquisitions of European companies. Over to you .......

BE

.... because I can't think of any.

PM

hmm

11:38 am
PM

that's a challenge

PM

Certainly nothing consumer facing

BE

So .......... in terms of the readthrough for the Sainsbury bid, there really isn't one.

11:38 am
BE

Argos didn't want it and Sainsbury didn't want it. It's a tidying exercise.

PM

Homebase detail here : http://www.investe...1601180700081327M/

BE

Or, if you prefer, Freddie George of Cantor can summarise.

11:39 am
BE

Homebase to be sold as expected – The company has confirmed that it will be selling Homebase to Wesfarmers for £340m in cash (33p per share after restructuring costs). Management intends to return £200m to shareholders after paying £50m into the pension scheme and providing £75m for restructuring costs. The transaction is expected to be completed by the first quarter of the company’s calendar year. A transitional
services agreement has been drawn up between Home Retail and Wesfarmers and the Argos digital concessions are likely to have to be withdrawn from Homebase over the next eighteen months. The deal is subject to approval from shareholders and the company’s banking syndicate.

BE

Break-up value of c.260p per share – Home Retail has one of the strongest balance sheets in the General Retail sector with cash forecast at £292m at February 2016, mail order debtors of £580m and relatively high levels of provisioning. It also has a break-up value of c.260p per share, including 106p attributable to the cash balance and the debtors file and incorporating a value of £340m for Homebase, significantly higher than most analyst expectations.

BE

PUSU of February 2, to remind.

11:40 am
PM

106p of cash?

BE

That includes the loan book, I think.

BE

As in, a very high interest rate quasi-credit card business that could be folded into Sainsbury's not hugely successful financial arm.

11:42 am
BE

I've mentioned before that CFO John Rogers seems central to Sainsbury's tilt at Argos.

BE

I'd also mentioned before that John Rogers was central to Sainsbury growing its bank by winding it out of a JV on what looked like very expensive terms.

BE

I think those two facts can't be ignored. Sainsbury wants Argos's loan book. That's a big, and slightly ignored, aspect of the deal so far.

11:44 am
BE

Quick line from Bernstein.

BE

Clearly it's all about the bid for HOME from Sainsbury's at the moment, the probability of which is increased by the sale of Homebase to Wesfarmer.

BE

We have long argued that Home Retail face significant structural challenges at Argos and that LFL sales growth is not ensured. We do not believe that an acquisition by Sainsbury's would dramatically change this. However, if Sainsbury's was able to retain Argos' sales, generate non-food sales growth and reduce costs through store closures, this would offer significant profit improvement potential to the business. Given the share price reaction since details of the bid emerged, we believe this was broadly understood. If no bid is forthcoming we believe the key questions going forward relate to Argos' ability to continue to deliver positive LFL sales growth and the potential for future operating leverage or de-leverage in the business. We are increasingly concerned about the impact of the living wage legislation as we believe Home to be both heavily exposed to minimum wage labour, but also competing with players that are not (e.g. Amazon and AOworld) adding another source of margin compression.

11:44 am
undefined
PM

Sorry dasv -- we don't know what is going on with the Italian banks

PM

Other than them being Italian

11:45 am
PM

But yes -- some big drops

PM

Unicredit down 4.8%

PM

etc

11:46 am
PM

Guess there's more detail on this bad bank plan

undefined
BE

Hey, mentioned that BP upgrade earlier.

11:48 am
BE

Which we said we would come back to, so we will.

BP PLC (BP.:LSE): Last: 344.00, up 5.85 (+1.73%), High: 344.65, Low: 333.10, Volume: 16.13m
BE

Sector view first, since it was requested.

11:49 am
BE

This is all pinned on $60 in 2017. So, just a 100% rebound required.

BE

Oil at $30 in H1 16 and $40/bbl in FY16, but $60 in FY17 Oil demand destruction in
China and the important-for-demand Middle East region, the imminent return of Iranian oil
where the risk is that production rises faster than expected and the continuing Saudi
market share policy are all factors driving large inventory builds in H1 16. We thus cut H1
Brent to $30/bbl and assume $40 in FY16 (from $55/bbl), with material reductions to gas
prices. But the call on OPEC oil should slowly rise in H2 16 as US output declines
accelerate, so the rate of inventory build should halve versus H1 16. Improving oil market
momentum will at some stage lead financial investors – currently sitting on their biggest
short positions in a decade – to close their positions. The process of cost adjustment is
unfolding, but slowly; the adjustment should elevate prices to $60/bbl next year we
estimate, supported by OPEC spare capacity at an all-time low. SG equity strategy team’s
Overweight oils call is predicated on such a price rise.

BE

Sector EPS downgrades Our 2016e sector earnings estimates are reduced by c.60%,
with Galp the most resilient in the group; and Total the most resilient oil major, which now
becomes our new preferred stock. Our new estimates stand materially below consensus
and the sector trades on a 45.6x 2016 P/E though on a more reasonable 12.4x 2017e. We
maintain flat dividend assumptions especially for the big majors, whose balance sheets in
our view are strong enough to absorb the hard times in 2015-16; but we note that the
derivatives markets are pricing in material reductions. If a year from now oil remains at
$30/bbl, it would be irresponsible of company boards not to address the issue of adjusting
distributions; but in a cyclical, slow-moving industry, we think this will not happen in 2016.
We upgrade BP from Hold to Buy on valuation upside and its early start on cost resetting -
hence we are now buyers of all three oil majors (BP, Shell, Total) on the view that for the
moment they will absorb the pain on the balance sheet. We see the Saipem
deconsolidation from Eni as strengthening its balance sheet; we think OMV, whilst FCF
positive, may need to trim dividends to protect its investment grade rating; and Repsol (our
least preferred) in a world of $30 (rather than its $50 stress case) may need more than
€1.5bn of new equity by year-end 2016 to protect its own investment grade.

11:50 am
PM

So this is a buy on the basis that if conditions persist, BP will need fresh equity

PM

Brilliant

PM

Where do I sign up?

11:51 am
BE

I was just coming to that, once I'd combed through the summary pages for anything to share.

BE

Basically, in terms of SocGen's overview: they say they were wrong, as was everyone else.

BE

And there's no way to know what'll happen next because everyone was wrong in an unprecedented way.

11:52 am
BE

But ....... oh, I dunno. Mean reversion happens. So, buy BP.

BE

Here's that bit.

BE

Reflecting our new commodity assumptions of a 2016e 27% lower Brent oil price,
23% lower Henry Hub and 27% lower UK gas price, we downgrade BP’s 2016e EPS by a deep
69% and by 25% in 2017e for the 7% lower Brent. Whilst at $40/bbl in 2016e free cash flow is
negative, at $60/bbl next year it should cover dividends. BP was the first in our coverage
universe to launch a strategy of “value over growth” back in 2011, and the rest have now come
to follow by also focusing on value/free cash flow. But as an early starter BP has an advantage –
it’s been resetting its cost structure to the smaller post portfolio footprint (with c.$55bn of
disposals BP post Macondo, the portfolio is one-third smaller since 2012/13) precisely because
post incident costs had escalated. Moreover, BP was the first to recognise very early in 2015
that oil could drop to $45/bbl and stay lower for longer – at a time when markets were still
expecting $80-90. The company moved quickly in 2015 to reset costs and capex for a
sustained low priced period and continues to adjust costs aggressively as seen in the 4,000
redundancies just announced: provisioning for such redundancies increased from the original
$1bn by end 2015 (disclosed in Dec 14) to the Q3 15 guidance of $2.5bn by end 2016.
Upstream unit production costs are 20% lower than in 2013 and it is reducing overall cash
costs by some $6bn by end 2017 (with $3bn delivered in the first 9 months 2015), out of a
“controllable” cost base of c.$26-27bn. On capex, it has materially lowered guidance from a
previous $24-26bn p.a. to $17-19bn in 2016-17. The portfolio’s reliability is up materially, non
productive time is at its lowest, and hence BP expects the near-term decline rates to be 2%,
compared with a normal 3-5% p.a.

11:53 am
BE

Its capex range of $17-19bn offers optionality, driven by timing FIDs so as to
capture cost deflation: 80% of its pre-FID projects have a sub $60/bbl cash breakeven, down
from c.$80/bbl before. Results are convincing: a 25% lower development cost per bbl at
Thunder Horse, and a 12% lower breakeven price at the West Nile Delta. The portfolio should
deliver 800kboed to net production from new start-ups by 2020, with 500kboed from seven
major projects under development. BP is convincingly moving to deliver its financial
framework of balancing 2017 sources and uses of cash at $60/bbl Brent, whilst prioritising
dividends, and is prepared to use the balance sheet during the 2016 cycle downturn to
deliver that. We view its 8.6% dividend yield as excessive in our scenario of a 2017 recovery
to $60. Our new cash and free cash flow estimates indicate that rebalancing is achievable.

BE

Which is a fun read.

undefined
11:54 am
BE

While doing sellside, today's miner rejig is from Cazenove.

BE

Buy the ones that don't need more capital. Or, failing that, buy the ones that have a chance of raising the capital they need.

BE

So, positive on Glencore (was Caz a bookrunner on the Glencore rescue, incidentally?)

11:55 am
Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 74.74, up 1.24 (+1.69%), High: 75.13, Low: 72.27, Volume: 23.50m
BE

Buy Rio ...

Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 1,662, up 18 (+1.10%), High: 1,668, Low: 1,612, Volume: 2.44m
11:56 am
BE

Buy S32 (didn't Caz do the S32 spinoff, incidentally?)

BE

Buy Anto. Don't buy any of the others. Here's the upshot of it.

BE

MACRO – A tough year in store: A combination of factors point to a
challenging macro backdrop this year. The US$ is expected to remain
strong, most commodities are in oversupply and China continues to slow
and tilt away from investment. Our strategists note that a 1pp move in
Chinese IP correlates with a ~3-4% move in commodity prices & FX.
Perhaps the best we can hope for is a denouement this year – weaker players
forced out of the market, commodity markets rebalanced, balance sheets
recapitalised and potential upside to 2017 forecasts. Even this outcome,
however, probably requires an ugly H1. An alternative, arguably gloomier,
outcome is a more grinding downtrend that extends into 2017 as the supplyside
muddles through without meaningful cuts to production

11:56 am
BE

COMMODITIES – Precious to outperform base & bulks; oil recovery
a wildcard: We make material changes to bulk prices. Iron ore -25%/-26%
for 2016/17E and -23% to $50/t (real) long term, met coal -14%-26%,
thermal -14%-17%. Our base metals forecasts are for YoY sequential price
falls in 2016/17E. We anticipate precious metals rising in H2 as DXY
begins to roll over and believe prices could record absolute upside through
2016. Oil remains the wildcard, with our base case forecast implying greater than 50%
upside to spot, potentially powerful but also up for debate.

BE

CURRENCIES – Mitigate EPS downside, but prolong weaker prices:
Producer currencies depreciated ~15-50% in 2015 and we expect ongoing
weakness in 2016. While this partially offsets commodity price falls, it has
amplified price deflation by lowering global cost curves. Uncertainty over
the path for CNY also has significant implications given China’s importance
on both the demand and supply sides of commodity markets. Our house
view is China will increasingly focus on the trade-weighted value of CNY;
the fact this is trading near record highs is not supportive for commodities.

BE

EARNINGS – Another year of negative momentum: Across the sector
we forecast average YoY EBITDA declines of ~25% (-98% to +23% range),
with greater than 80% of the sector expected to record negative bottom-line earnings
for 2016; 2017 sees a further 38% YoY decline. The exception is precious,
where we forecast only slight EBITDA declines due to supportive prices.

11:57 am
BE

SECTOR STRATEGY – Safety & catalysts key to outperformance: Among
the diversified miners, we retain our preference for GLEN and RIO. GLEN offers
a clear set of catalysts (Agriculture sale, refinancing loan facilities, 32% FCF
yield on spot) that can improve credit risk perception and drive equity upside (PT
£1.30/sh, +75% upside). RIO still offers relative safety, and while there is
legitimate debate over the sustainability of a ~10% yield on a two-year view, we
believe 2016 risk is low (PT £17.50/sh, +6%). We believe a strong recovery in oil
is already captured in BHP's valuation, and credit rating pressure could provoke a
larger dividend cut than the ~50% currently priced; we now assume the cut
occurs with H1 results in February.

BE

DEEP VALUE – Present, but catalysts unclear/uncertain: AAL is perhaps the
best example of deep value, with our base case P/NPV at just 0.58x. We retain
our UW, however, with FCF negative until FY’19E and uncertainty over the
company's ability to deliver the aggressive restructuring that was roughly
outlined in December. Nonetheless, there is headline risk into February results.
KAZ (d/grade to N), and FQM (N) also offer scope for positive catalysts (debt
renegotiations, asset sales), however, in both cases extreme gearing to commodity
prices stops us becoming more constructive.
 OTHER CHANGES: We downgrade NHY (N) and remove it from the AFL,
with the shares having outperformed peers solidly over the past year and cash
flow risks building. We upgrade ANTO (to OW) now M&A and project risk has
receded while downgrading KAZ (N), and KGH (UW). We see upside potential
in both FRES (OW, £10.90/sh, +58%) and ACA (OW, £3.10/sh, +84%), who
should benefit from higher prices and lower costs.

Antofagasta PLC (ANTO:LSE): Last: 354.10, up 3.5 (+1.00%), High: 356.60, Low: 343.10, Volume: 1.47m
11:57 am
Kaz Minerals PLC (KAZ:LSE): Last: 85.00, down 4.75 (-5.29%), High: 90.25, Low: 85.00, Volume: 327.44k
PM

Kaz no longer tethered to Glencore?

PM

Not today, clearly

11:59 am
undefined
PM

We must mention Rocket before finishing

PM

Down another 4%

11:59 am
PM

18 euros now

PM

It really is Stick Internet

PM

Let me just get the chart post float

12:00 pm
PM
